context: Gain of function (activating) mutations on the GLUD1 gene increase GDH1 activity by rendering this isoenzyme resistant to the allosteric inhibition by GTP while retaining the stimulatory action of ADP and L-leucine, resulting in a constitutive enzyme overactivity that leads to the hyperinsulinism hyperammonemia syndrome. Affected patients manifest hyperammonemia and recurrent fasting or postprandial hypoglycemia episodes related to enhanced insulin release by pancreatic β-cells thought to be due to an excess of intracellular ATP. In the liver, it is believed that overactivity of GDH1 leads to hyperammonemia by increasing free ammonium ions generation due to unrestrained oxidation of glutamate. Additionally, GDH1 overactivity might result in glutamate depletion, reducing N-acetylglutamate formation and consequently preventing urea cycle initiation.Aminotransferases (transaminases) Aminotransferases catalyze the reversible transfer of α-amino groups from α-amino acids to α-ketoacids without producing or consuming free ammonium ions. The reversible transport of amino groups between alanine/pyruvate, aspartate/oxaloacetate, and branched-chain amino acids/branched-chain keto acids, takes place via coupled reactions with the partner pair glutamate/α-ketoglutarate (Fig. 5 ). Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) transports the α-amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate with the generation of pyruvate and glutamate. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) catalyzes the transfer of α-amino groups from aspartate to α-ketoglutarate with the formation of oxaloacetate and glutamate.
